title-group.article-title: The great mimic: syphilis mimicking testicular tumour. Conservative management using antibiotics alone with testicular sparing

abstract.title: Summary
abstract.p: We present the case of a 47-year-old man who attended a genitourinary (GU) medicine clinic with posthitis and a painless testicular mass on examination. Initial ultrasound revealed a 2-cm well-defined hypoechoic mass within the right testis and he was referred to urology on suspicion of malignancy. Subsequent syphilis serology was positive and the penile lesion and testicular mass were felt to be consistent with syphilis. After liaising with the urology department, and in view of negative tumour markers (lactate dehydrogenase, alfa-fetoprotein and human chorionic gonadotrophin) and known penicillin allergy, he was managed conservatively with four weeks of oral doxycycline. Follow-up ultrasound scans revealed adequate response of the testicular mass, with the last scan, performed at 10 months post-treatment, showing complete resolution. This is the first documented case of conservative management of a testicular syphilitic lesion using antibiotics alone with testicular sparing.

sec.title: CASE REPORT
sec.p: A 47-year-old man who has sex with men (MSM) presented to genitourinary (GU) medicine clinic complaining of a two-month history of foreskin swelling and itch. He had no other symptoms, with no history of underlying skin problems. This was his first presentation to a GU medicine clinic with no previous history of sexually transmitted infection. He was allergic to penicillin, with documented widespread rash on previous penicillin administration. He reported inconsistent condom use with a regular male partner of three months, with no other sexual partners in the past year.

On examination, faint, patchy, macular lesions were present over the mid penile shaft. A large, well demarcated, non-ulcerating, erythematous, indurated area was present on the subprepuce, with no meatitis or discharge noted. Testicular examination revealed a firm, non-tender swelling in the right testis, adjacent to the epididymis. The left testis was normal on palpation.

Syphilis serology was positive; Treponemal Immunoglobulin M enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (IgM ELISA) positive, syphilis Immunoglobulin M and G enzyme immunoassay (EIA) positive, Serodia particle agglutination assay (TPPA) 1:1280 and Venereal Diseases Research Laboratory (VDRL) titre 1:32. HIV antibody/antigen was negative, as was Chlamydia trachomatis polymerase chain reaction (PCR), herpes simplex virus PCR and Neisseria gonorrhoeae culture. Subpreputial skin swab grew skin flora and Streptococcus viridians (considered to be unrelated commensals). The patient was recalled for repeat examination to screen for cardiovascular and neurological complications of syphilis, which were absent. He was also referred for an urgent scrotal ultrasound scan (see Figure 1). Figure 1
Ultrasound scan of the right testis, showing a 2-cm well-defined, hypoechoic focal testicular mass close to the epididymis
His tumour markers were checked, with normal serum levels of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), alfa-fetoprotein (AFP) and human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG) detected.

Following discussion between urologists, GU medicine clinicians and radiologists, in view of previous reports of syphilitic lesions mimicking testicular tumours,1–8 conservative treatment was initiated with four weeks of oral doxycycline 100 mg twice daily (in view of penicillin allergy), with close monitoring clinically, biochemically and radiologically. The patient was actively involved in the discussion process and consented to conservative management with regular ultrasound follow-up under the urologists.

His skin lesions improved with antibiotic treatment and subsequent ultrasound scans, at four, seven and 10 months, demonstrated shrinking of the testicular mass with complete resolution (Figures 2–4), supporting the diagnosis of a non-malignant mass. Figure 2

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: Syphilitic lesions of the testes are well described in textbooks, but now rarely seen in practice. The infection is caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum, and is transmitted sexually upon direct contact with an infectious lesion, vertically, or through infected blood products.9 It can be classified as acquired or congenital, with acquired syphilis subdivided into primary, secondary, early latent (within 2 years of infection), late latent (after 2 years of infection) or tertiary (gummatous, cardiovascular or neurosyphilis). Congenital syphilis is divided into early (presenting within 2 years of life) or late (presenting after 2 years of life).

A comprehensive literature search revealed 12 case reports of syphilis presenting in the testes and epididymis in the last 60 years; three in Japan,1–3 six4 in Europe and three5–7 in the UK. In all the cases, a diagnosis of syphilis was reached following radical orchidectomy for suspected testicular cancer, either histologically or on serology.

In the above case, the clinical findings likely represent early syphilis presenting as a testicular mass mimicking malignancy as opposed to a gumma. A positive IgM ELISA on serology also supports this diagnosis. Testicular gummas are more common with late syphilis, with patients developing gradual painless enlargement of the testis, with little epididymal involvement, giving rise to a ‘billiard ball’ testis, which is ‘woody hard’ on palpation.8 The decision to treat as per late latent syphilis is based on the lack of previous negative syphilis serology to accurately time the infection, although it is more likely the patient contracted the infection within the last two years.

This is the first case of conservative management of testicular syphilis using antibiotics alone. It is made possible with effective multidisciplinary input from the urologists and GU medicine physicians, with support from radiology. It also highlights the importance of testing for rare causes of testicular lumps presenting as malignancy.
